case.name: Model Verification and Validation Pattern
case.description: An argument pattern for independent auditing and assurance of ML/AI models, particularly for regulatory contexts such as IFRS 9 ECL estimation. This pattern decomposes model acceptability into trustworthiness properties (reliability, explainability, security, fairness, data quality, governance) with explicit assumptions and defeaters.

tree.name: G0
tree.description: Model M is acceptable for deployment in context C.
context: [Instantiate: Specify the model M being validated]
[Instantiate: Specify the deployment context C, including regulatory requirements (e.g., IFRS 9, SR 11-7, EU AI Act)]
[Instantiate: Define acceptability criteria relevant to the deployment context]
tree.justification: Model acceptability is demonstrated through argument over distinct trustworthiness properties, each of which must be satisfied for the model to be fit for purpose.

children.name: S0
children.description: Argument over trustworthiness properties: decompose model acceptability into reliability, explainability, security, fairness, data quality, governance, and residual risk management.
children.justification: Trustworthiness properties provide a comprehensive and modular framework for model validation that aligns with regulatory expectations and best practices in model risk management.

children.name: G1
children.description: Model M is sufficiently reliable.
context: [Instantiate: Define reliability thresholds for the deployment context]

children.name: S1.1
children.description: Argument over performance dimensions: demonstrate reliability through discriminatory power, calibration, and segmented performance.

children.name: P1.1
children.description: Discriminatory power metrics (e.g., AUC, Gini coefficient) meet defined thresholds.

children.name: E1.1.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Test set evaluation results from validation pipeline]

children.name: P1.2
children.description: Model calibration is acceptable: predicted probabilities align with observed frequencies.

children.name: E1.2.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Calibration plots, Hosmer-Lemeshow test results, or equivalent]

children.name: P1.3
children.description: Performance is stable across relevant segments (e.g., customer segments, product types, time periods).

children.name: E1.3.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Segmented performance analysis report]

children.name: S1.2
children.description: Argument over temporal stability: demonstrate reliability through backtesting and sensitivity analysis.

children.name: P1.4
children.description: Backtesting shows acceptable alignment between predicted and realised outcomes over the validation period.

children.name: E1.4.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Backtesting report with prediction vs. outcome analysis]

children.name: P1.5
children.description: Sensitivity to input drift is characterised and within acceptable bounds.

children.name: E1.5.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Sensitivity analysis results and drift tolerance thresholds]

children.name: A1
children.description: [ASSUMPTION] Test data is representative of the deployment distribution.
children.assumption: The validation test set adequately represents the population and conditions under which the model will be deployed. If this assumption is violated, performance estimates may not generalise.

children.name: G2
children.description: Model M is sufficiently explainable.
context: [Instantiate: Define explainability requirements for stakeholders (auditors, regulators, end users)]

children.name: S2.1
children.description: Argument over interpretability: demonstrate that model structure and feature contributions can be understood.

children.name: P2.1
children.description: Model structure permits inspection: either inherently interpretable or equipped with validated explanation methods.

children.name: E2.1.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Model architecture documentation or explanation method validation]

children.name: P2.2
children.description: Feature contributions are attributable: the influence of input features on outputs can be quantified and explained.

children.name: E2.2.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Feature importance analysis, SHAP values, or equivalent attribution method results]

children.name: S2.2
children.description: Argument over justifiability: demonstrate that model outputs can be explained to relevant stakeholders.

children.name: P2.3
children.description: Outputs can be explained to stakeholders in terms they understand and find meaningful.

children.name: E2.3.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Stakeholder comprehension study or explanation template documentation]

children.name: P2.4
children.description: Key decisions (e.g., staging decisions in IFRS 9 context) have traceable rationale that can be audited.

children.name: E2.4.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Decision audit trail documentation or case-level explanation logs]

children.name: D2
children.description: [DEFEATER] Post-hoc explanations may not reflect true model reasoning.
context: Post-hoc explanation methods (e.g., SHAP, LIME) approximate model behaviour but may not faithfully represent the model's actual decision process, particularly for complex models.

children.name: G3
children.description: Model M is sufficiently secure.
context: [Instantiate: Define security requirements and threat model]

children.name: S3.1
children.description: Argument over adversarial robustness: demonstrate resilience to adversarial inputs and data poisoning.

children.name: P3.1
children.description: Model behaviour is stable under adversarial perturbations relevant to the threat model.

children.name: E3.1.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Adversarial robustness testing results]

children.name: S3.2
children.description: Argument over access controls: demonstrate that model access is appropriately restricted.

children.name: P3.2
children.description: Access controls prevent unauthorised model queries, training data access, and model extraction.

children.name: E3.2.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Security architecture documentation and penetration testing results]

children.name: G4
children.description: Model M is sufficiently fair.
context: [Instantiate: Define fairness criteria and protected characteristics relevant to the context]

children.name: S4.1
children.description: Argument over group fairness metrics: demonstrate equitable treatment across protected groups.

children.name: P4.1
children.description: Group fairness metrics (e.g., demographic parity, equalised odds) are within acceptable thresholds.

children.name: E4.1.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Fairness metrics analysis across protected groups]

children.name: S4.2
children.description: Argument over individual fairness: demonstrate consistent treatment of similar individuals.

children.name: P4.2
children.description: Similar individuals receive similar predictions, controlling for legitimate differentiating factors.

children.name: E4.2.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Individual fairness analysis or counterfactual testing results]

children.name: A4
children.description: [ASSUMPTION] Protected characteristics are known and measurable.
children.assumption: Fairness analysis requires data on protected characteristics. If this data is unavailable or unreliable, fairness claims are limited to proxy analysis.

children.name: G5
children.description: Model M operates on data of sufficient quality.
context: [Instantiate: Define data quality requirements for the model's intended use]

children.name: S5.1
children.description: Argument over data provenance: demonstrate that data sources are known, authorised, and appropriate.

children.name: P5.1
children.description: Data lineage is documented from source to model input, including all transformations.

children.name: E5.1.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Data lineage documentation]

children.name: S5.2
children.description: Argument over data integrity: demonstrate that data is accurate, complete, and correctly processed.

children.name: P5.2
children.description: Data quality metrics (completeness, accuracy, consistency, timeliness) meet defined thresholds.

children.name: E5.2.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Data quality assessment report]

children.name: P5.3
children.description: Feature engineering logic is documented, reviewed, and correctly implemented.

children.name: E5.3.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Feature engineering documentation and code review records]

children.name: G6
children.description: Model M is governed appropriately.
context: [Instantiate: Define governance requirements from regulatory frameworks and organisational policies]

children.name: S6.1
children.description: Argument over accountability structures: demonstrate clear ownership and responsibility.

children.name: P6.1
children.description: Model ownership, development responsibility, and validation responsibility are clearly assigned.

children.name: E6.1.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Model inventory entry with RACI matrix]

children.name: S6.2
children.description: Argument over change management: demonstrate controlled model updates and versioning.

children.name: P6.2
children.description: Model changes follow documented approval processes with appropriate validation before deployment.

children.name: E6.2.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Change management policy and recent change approval records]

children.name: S6.3
children.description: Argument over ongoing monitoring: demonstrate that model performance is continuously tracked.

children.name: P6.3
children.description: Monitoring systems detect material performance degradation and trigger escalation procedures.

children.name: E6.3.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Monitoring architecture documentation]

children.name: E6.3.2
children.description: [Instantiate: Drift detection alert logs from monitoring pipeline]

children.name: E6.3.3
children.description: [Instantiate: Escalation procedure documentation]

children.name: G7
children.description: Residual risks are identified and mitigated.
context: This goal addresses risks that remain after satisfying G1-G6, including unresolved defeaters and violated assumptions.

children.name: S7.1
children.description: Argument over known limitations: demonstrate that model limitations are documented and communicated.

children.name: P7.1
children.description: Known limitations and boundary conditions for valid model use are documented and communicated to users.

children.name: E7.1.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Model limitation documentation and user guidance materials]

children.name: S7.2
children.description: Argument over compensating controls: demonstrate that controls address residual risks.

children.name: P7.2
children.description: Compensating controls (e.g., human review, override mechanisms, fallback procedures) are in place for identified residual risks.

children.name: E7.2.1
children.description: [Instantiate: Compensating controls documentation and effectiveness assessment]
